utterances: Well, Professor Lewis, when you think about solutions, you've mention some very good ones for individuals, but what about the whole idea of diversity training?
It's something that some people go to a company and they're kind of compelled to go through some kind of training, other people, it'll never come up.
But what do you think of the whole idea of what diversity training is, and whether or not it's effective?

Well, I think diversity training in its original context out of this multiculturalism movement, in which everyone comes in and explores their differences and agrees to be happy to be different, doesn't actually help us move that far along in the workplace.

Instead, I like the models of people like Carmen Van Kerckhove with New Demographic, or Rashawn Ray with Engaged Diversity, where people start with discussing who they are and how those identities matter for privilege and power.
If we're talking about differences at work, we have to really recognize that some people have more of an ability to be who they are openly, and other people have less.
And how can we reshape the conversation not to just concentrate on difference, but differences in power, privilege and the potential to create a collaborative space.
How would you rate your own experience?
Meaning, you're a professor, and academia can be very politicized, but it's also a place where, you know, these discussions are not considered totally out of the blue.
How would you rate the kind of conversations that go on in the context in which you operate?
I think for many people, it'd be hard to believe that academia struggles with the same issues.
It's a workplace environment.
Just because people maybe professionals, it doesn't mean that they're necessarily use to dealing with these issues.
So one of the first things I have to recognize as a young African-American male is that I'm often elected to be a role model, or serve on committees of diversity requirements.
What is important for me is to make sure to hold back and not jump at every opportunity that's provided.
Because in spaces that have historically not included people who or African-American, the institution can be very excited to have you present and wants you to do work.
But those additional burdens of work can also prohibit me from doing my primary job of researching and educating students.
So it sounds like there is - you know, the idea of the black man's burden as it translates to the workplace.

Like, a lot of black folks who I know - and not just black folks, but people who have identities that are not the most common at their workplace - say, well, why should I do all the work of educating people?
Right.
And it's very important that we as individuals recognize that there are entire firms and groups who work on making sure that these issues can actually be discussed in productive manners.
So my job is to educate people on race, but it's not my job to coach my colleagues on being anti-racist, anti-sexist or overly hetero-normative, or working against hetero-normativity.
You have to create the space to make your contribution, but also knowing to step back.
Because taking that burden too far will mean that you probably won't be successful as your own job, as you attempt to educate your colleagues.
All right.
Thank you so much.
Thanks for having me.
CHIDEYA.
That was R.
L'Heureux Lewis, assistant professor of sociology and black studied at the City College of New York, and he joined us from NPR studios in New York.
And now we're going take the discussion to the life of the docks.
The busiest ports in the country are right here in the backyard of our studio.
The ports of Long Beach in Los Angeles see roughly 16 million containers every year carrying everything from toilet paper to pickup trucks.
Somebody has to unload and coordinate all that cargo, and it's not always a man.
I've got Clovijean Good sitting with me here in the studio.
She's a member of Southern California's Local 94 of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union.
Great to have you with us.
Hello, how are you doing today?
I'm doing great.
And it's great to see you.
So take me back to 1984, when you first became what's called a longshoreman casual.
What does that mean?
A longshore casual, that's part-time work in the industry.
When they have a overflow of work, they have to hire part-time workers.
But what does a longshoreman - well, first of all, do you call yourself a longshoreman, woman, person, how do you...?
I call myself a longshoreman.
That's the name, and that's the name that I go by.
But you have a lot women that would prefer to be called Longshorewoman.
OK, so what do you do?
They're very - they would be very, I think - they would like to have this over with, so the climbers on the south side can continue up the mountain and all of this controversy goes away.
But the climbers will be challenged to be ready to go after May 10th, if there is an early weather window.
Yes I'm sorry, I didn't get that part.
I - we import, export, stevedoring.
We load, unload vessels.
We receive cargo that has to be shipped out to different countries.
and we load and unload ships, organize the hold operation.
When I first started, I was a part-time worker, and we just work longshore.
Longshore workers basically handle the labor part.
Then as time went on, I became a marine clerk, which - we organize everything that has to be done for us loading and unloading the vessels.
And now in my latter years, my 24th year, I'm long shore foreman, where actually I am a walking boss over longshoremen.
I'm their boss.
Your dad set an example for you.
What road did he have to walk to do what he did?
My father was a young man who became a longshoreman in the early '60s.
And as we all know back in the early '60s, African-Americans was not given the opportunities as other different nationalities.
So he was one of the first men that had to take on that struggle and had to fight for his rights to be able to be a skilled longshoreman.
To be able to do all different aspects of the job, and to open the doors so that when I decided to walk into the doors, that I would have an opportunity.
There were moments when he had a hard time, right, dealing with his co-workers?
Oh, yes.
Yes, a lot of hard times.
You know, they wasn't accustomed to African-American men driving winches.
They was only given to a certain category of men.
So he had to take on those struggles to teach himself.
No one was teaching him, training him.
And he had to take on the responsibility of demanding the job, going out and working the job when everyone would leave off the vessels and didn't even want to work with an African-American man.
Like they didn't want - you walked in a restaurant, they didn't want to eat in the same restaurant with you.
They also did not want to work on the same vessels.
What did he say when his baby girl wanted to go in and take this kind of a job?
Oh, he did not want that.
He did not want his daughter on the waterfront.
He felt that he has struggled long and far enough, and that he didn't want me in that type of environment.
Why did you want to do it?
Because I was - you know, they say apple don't fall too far from the tree.
I knew that it was a great career, I knew that it was excellent money and I knew that I could become a great independent woman, help myself and help others.
So I decided to - that I had to do it.
What were the - some of the - or give me an example of one of the worst moments that you've had to deal with, and one of the best moments that you've had to deal with in your career.
Well, I would say one of the worst moments is - you know as a African-American woman, they - the different cultures did not want to - I'm an aggressor.
I want the best.
I want to be the boss.
I want to run the operation.
And I had to take on that challenge.
And so I had a lot of bad days because of - people were, everybody was fighting against a woman or African-American woman, climbing the ladder.
There was a glass ceiling there.
So I had plenty of challenging days where I had to fight for my rights.
So...
What do you mean by that?
What do you mean by fight for your rights?
Well, you know, I took on my employer.
You know, I went ahead and I sued them, and I did what I had to do to break the glass ceiling so that women, African-American women and everyone, can have an equal employment opportunity.
What are, or were, some of the good moments?
I mean, sounds like you've moved up in the game.
Oh, the good moments is that, you know, I love the people.
You know, I love going to work, I love the challenge, I love being the one who is running this big trillion-dollar operation.
So every day that I go to work, you know, is a good day.
You know, you can talk about the bad and things that have happened, but at the of the day, it's all been a good day.
Because you can teach people, you can train people, you can advise people on how to grow, how to, you know, learn how to drive a crane or go learn how to be a marine clerk.
So those are the good days, because you can teach.
I mean, I had the power to be able to teach and instruct with no problem.
Have you ever felt that you had to try to leave yourself at the door as a black woman?
No, I'm not leaving myself at the door.
When I walk in, I walk in as Clovijean Good.
I know that I'm a beautiful person, I know that I hold God within my heart.
So when I walk in the door, I walk in being who I am.
Who do you mentor?
My father.
You mentor your father.
No, I don't mentor him.
You know what?
I mentor - I have a group of girls, 15 girls at the Los Angeles Will Rodgers Boys and Girls Club.
Uh huh.
You're only supposed to have one girl, but, you know, I'm fortunate to have 15.
That's a lot.
Yes.
So I mentor 15 girls.
That's a secret, though.
Not everybody know I really do that.
But I mentor...
Oh, they will know.
Yeah.
I mentor every young lady that comes across my path.
You know, that's what I do.
I buy books, and talk to children, and talk to girls, and teach them how to be better individuals.
Do you ever - do any of them express an interest in being a longshoreman?
You know, a lot of people, everybody I know expressed the interest in being a longshoreman.
I get phone calls every single day.
But you know, I always just tell them to get their education.
You know, you don't know what - what you're going to do as you grow.

So as long as you apply yourself and get good education and have some type of path, that you're working for some goal that you're working for, you have no idea what boat is going to ride by that you get to jump on.
One of the favorite things that I see when I look at you is that you have this very extravagant pen with a big silk yellow rose on it.
And it's a very feminine part of who you are, and you're working in this very masculine field.
Why are you carrying that pen?
You know, this is my good luck pen.
My auntie, she made me about 12 of them, and everywhere I go I take - because I'm a writer.
I usually write notes, take notes and - so I can always know what I'm talking about and being prepared.
So I always carry this pen with me.
You know, it's my writing tube, but I am very soft.
So it's, you know, it's a part of me.
All right.
Well, Clovijean, it's great to hear from you, and that sounds like you and your dad are quite a team.
